title: Ernesto Becomes Cat 1 Hurricane
message:
(Miami, FL) -- The National Hurricane Center says the storm system Ernesto is now a Category 1 Hurricane.
Almost half of Puerto Rico and more than 90 percent of the Virgin Islands are without power.
Significant flooding is also expected across Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
Strengthening is forecast during the next couple of days, and Ernesto could become a major hurricane by Friday.
The Bermuda Weather Service has issued a Hurricane Watch for Bermuda.

title: July 2024 sets new records for global heat and climate disasters
message:
According to a global extreme heat analysis from Climate Central , human-driven climate change continues to be the culprit for the powerful heat waves thanks to activities like burning coal and deforestation.
Earth's average temperature for the month of July was the highest in National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s 175-year book, inching up 2.18 degrees Fahrenheit (1.21 degrees Celsius) from the 20th-century average of 60.4 degrees Fahrenheit (15.8 degrees Celsius).
In the U.S., July's average temperature came in at the 11th warmest in 130 years at 75.7 degrees Fahrenheit (24.3 degrees Celsius).
A map of the U.S. plotted with 11 weather and climate disasters each costing $1 billion or more that occurred between January and July, 2024.
NOAA records began back in 1980, and since then, there have been 395 different climate and weather disasters with the cost totaling $2.770 trillion.

title: Ernesto becomes a hurricane
message:
Ernesto gained strength and became a hurricane on Wednesday with winds of 75 miles per hour.
Ernesto may reach major hurricane status which is category 3 or higher.
Hurricane Ernesto is headed toward Bermuda which is an island in the Atlantic well off the U.S. East Coast.
The National Hurricane Center says, "Hurricane conditions are possible on Bermuda on Saturday, with tropical storm conditions possible by Friday afternoon.
Rainfall associated with Ernesto may begin to affect Bermuda as early as Thursday and result in flash flooding across Bermuda later in the week and this weekend."
event_breakdown: The National Hurricane Center is warning Bermuda that Hurricane Ernesto is headed toward them which could cause flash flooding later this weekend. They are advising Bermuda to prepare now.

title: Ernesto becomes hurricane after leaving 570 , 000 without power in Puerto Rico
message:
(NEW YORK) — Ernesto has become a Category 1 hurricane Wednesday after hitting Puerto Rico overnight and leaving power outages and flooding in its wake.
The center of then-Tropical Storm Ernesto passed within 40 miles of San Juan, Puerto Rico, early Wednesday, producing strong winds and heavy rain.
More than 570,000 customers are without power in Puerto Rico, according to LUMA, a service provider.
The storm was moving away from Puerto Rico on Wednesday morning with hurricane strength winds of 75 mph.
Tropical storm warnings were issued for Puerto Rico and a hurricane watch was in effect for the British Virgin Islands.

title: Japan – and world economy – at high risk of crippling megaquake : Chinese seismologist
message:
The warning from the Seismological Society of China comes just days after a magnitude 7.1 earthquake originating in the Nankai Trough area hit the Japanese island of Kyushu.
The risk of a mega earthquake from a fault line off the east coast of Japan is high, with potentially devastating threats to millions of people living in the zone and to the global economy.
“Cities near the Nankai Trough, especially in the Chugoku and Kansai clusters, are key economic centres, accounting for 70 per cent of Japan’s manufacturing,” he said.
Gao said the trough generated a major earthquake about every 117 years and the likelihood of another one remained high.
“The last significant earthquake in 1946, which resulted in a 6.9-metre tsunami, underscores the high probability of future seismic events,” he said.
event_breakdown: Japan: A magnitude 7.1 earthquake originating in the Nankai Trough area hit the Japanese island of Kyushu on Friday.

event_breakdown:
Three powerful earthquakes hit the Pacific on Thursday, sending shudders as far as Tokyo and triggering a tsunami advisory for coastal Japan.
The first quake, with a magnitude of 7.3, struck in the sea east of New Zealand's North Island at a depth of 19 kilometres, the US Geological Survey said.
The tremor rattled buildings in the capital Wellington, 650 kilometres north of the epicentre, and sent items tumbling from shelves.
A second 7.3-magnitude quake hit south-east of Fiji, followed by a 6.9-magnitude tremor near the same area, the US agency said.
The USGS said the third quake was also at a depth of 19 kilometres.

message:

title: 9am update : Hurricane Warning in effect
message:
First Prev 1 2 Next LastThursday 6am update: Hurricane Warning in effectThe Bermuda Weather Service issued a Hurricane Warning as of its 6am update, with Ernesto gearing up to make a direct hit on the island.
Winds will continue to intensify overnight, with Bermuda expected to experience Category 1 hurricane winds of 75mph to 80mph by Saturday morning.
“Ernesto is forecast to be a large hurricane near Bermuda on Saturday,” the NHC said.
“We could be dealing with a major hurricane approaching Bermuda this weekend,” warned Alex DaSilva, a hurricane expert with AccuWeather.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, following Hurricane Beryl, Hurricane Debby, Tropical Storm Alberto and Tropical Storm Chris.
event_breakdown:
Bermuda: A Hurricane Warning is in effect as Ernesto approaches the island.
Ernesto: A Category 1 hurricane with winds of 75mph to 80mph, approaching Bermuda.

title: Hurricane Ernesto drops torrential rain on Puerto Rico while pummeling northeast Caribbean
message:
Hurricane Ernesto dropped torrential rain on Puerto Rico and knocked out power for nearly half of all customers in the U.S. territory Wednesday as it threatened to grow into a major hurricane en route to Bermuda.
“I know it was a long night listening to that wind howl,” U.S. Virgin Islands Gov.
More than 140 flights were canceled to and from Puerto Rico.
More than 640,000 customers lost power in Puerto Rico, and 23 hospitals were operating on generators, Gov.
Rooftop solar systems are scarce but keep growing in Puerto Rico, where fossil fuels generate 94% of the island's electricity.

title: Hurricane Ernesto churns toward Bermuda as Category 1 storm – Connect FM | Local News Radio
message:
ABC News(NEW YORK) — Hurricane Ernesto is expected to strengthen into a major hurricane over the coming days as it travels northwards toward Bermuda, having already left half of Puerto Rico residents without power on Wednesday.
It is expected to gather strength through the coming weekend, possibly growing from a Category 1 to Category 3 hurricane.
By Friday night, the storm is expected to approach Bermuda as a Category 2 hurricane with winds of up to 110 mph.
After churning past Bermuda, Ernesto is projected to continue north and brush the Canadian coast near Newfoundland.
Puerto Rico suffered flash flooding, storm damage, and widespread power outages on Wednesday as Ernesto moved past the island.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto strengthens into hurricane after knocking out power in Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto strengthened into a hurricane on Wednesday, after bringing “significant flooding” to Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands and moved north.
More than 700,000 customers in Puerto Rico – half of all customers on the island – were without power Wednesday, according to LUMA Energy, the private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
President Biden approved an emergency declaration for Puerto Rico, with the White House saying they were authorizing FEMA to help with storm recovery.
The hurricane center said the storm is expected to produce between 4 and 6 inches of rain over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and up to 10 inches across southeastern Puerto Rico.
Flash flooding and mudslides could occur in the U.S. territories, the hurricane center said, as Ernesto continues bring “ongoing heavy rains.”Ernesto marks the fifth named storm so far of the Atlantic hurricane season.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Barry
As of 10 p.m. ET Friday, Tropical Storm Barry was about 40 miles south of the mouth of the Mississippi and 85 miles south of Morgan City, Louisiana, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph, with higher gusts, the center said.
The center said residents who live in areas outside the levee protection system should do their best to evacuate. Parts of southeast Louisiana are expected to get up to 25 inches of rain.
Authorities are monitoring the storm as it creeps toward the Gulf Coast. As of 2 a.m. ET Saturday, the hurricane center said Barry's winds are swirling at about 40 mph, and it is slowly moving toward the north.

title: Typhoon Ampil : Japan cancels flights and suspends bullet trains ahead of storm
message:
CNN —Japanese railways and airlines are canceling services as Typhoon Ampil gathers strength in the western Pacific, with the storm expected to hit on Friday during the peak summer travel season.
As of early Thursday local time, Typhoon Ampil was recording sustained winds of 140 kph (85 mph), according to the latest advisory from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC).
Two major airlines, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, canceled about 500 flights in total serving the capital’s Haneda and Narita airports, according to public broadcaster NHK.
The storm’s center is expected to remain slightly offshore as it turns toward the northeast and moves away from Japan, according to JTWC and Japan’s Meteorological Agency.
The storm is expected to weaken by Saturday morning local time and die down as it moves into cooler waters over the weekend.

title: Coast Guard Foundation Activates Emergency Disaster Relief Program
message:
Organization Provides Direct Support to Coast Guard Members Impacted by Hurricanes Beryl, Tropical Storm Debby and Other Natural DisastersThe Coast Guard Foundation, a non-profit organization committed to strengthening the Coast Guard community and service by supporting members and families, announced that its emergency disaster relief program is providing vital assistance to Coast Guard members and their families impacted by Hurricanes Beryl, Tropical Storm Debby, and glacial flooding in Juneau, Alaska.
In response to these natural disasters, the Coast Guard Foundation has activated its emergency disaster relief program to provide immediate assistance to Coast Guard members who have been directly affected.
Susan Ludwig, president of the Coast Guard Foundation, expressed her gratitude for the dedication and resilience of Coast Guard members during this difficult time.
To support the Coast Guard Foundation’s emergency disaster relief program, visit coastguardfoundation.org/disaster-relief.
To learn more about the Coast Guard Foundation, or to help support its work, please visit www.coastguardfoundation.org or call (860) 535-0786.

title: Hurricane Ernesto tracks toward Bermuda , will churn up dangerous seas for East Coast this weekend
message:
Beyond Bermuda, Ernesto will pass close to Atlantic Canada early next week and potentially bring some rain, wind and rough seas.
In the US Virgin Islands, about 32,000 customers were without power Thursday afternoon, more than half of the island’s tracked customers, according to PowerOutage.us.
More than half a foot of rain drenched much of Puerto Rico and caused widespread flash flooding.
Ernesto's floodwaters inundated Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico, Wednesday.
Even as Ernesto moved a few hundred miles away from Puerto Rico Wednesday night, water issues worsened.
event_breakdown:
1. Puerto Rico: Ernesto caused widespread flash flooding, and as of Thursday morning, 40,000 people were still without power. Most of the island will escape major damage, but landslides and overflowing rivers are possible in mountainous areas.
2. British Virgin Islands: Heavy rains and rough seas from the hurricane battered the coast, and power outages were reported in some areas.
3. Bahamas: Although the storm spared the country a direct hit, Ernesto still caused rough seas and dangerous surf conditions.
4. U.S. Virgin Islands: More than 31,000 customers were without power Thursday afternoon, following severe flooding and power outages caused by the storm.
5. Atlantic Ocean: Ernesto is heading toward Atlantic Canada and is expected to bring rain, wind and rough seas to the region.

title: Japan megaquake alert ends amid no major new seismic activity - Nikkei Asia
message:
The Nankai Trough megaquake advisory, the first since the system was implemented in 2017, prompted the central government and local communities to intensify disaster preparations over the past week.
The advisory is intended to inform the public of the higher-than-usual risk of a large-scale quake around the Nankai Trough for a week.
The Nankai Trough is an ocean-floor trench that runs along Japan's Pacific coast where the Eurasian and Philippine Sea tectonic plates meet.
The government estimates that, in a worst-case scenario, a megaquake in the Nankai Trough could result in over 200 trillion yen ($1.36 trillion) in damage.
History shows that a major earthquake around the Nankai Trough occurs every 100 to 150 years.

After sweeping past Taiwan's east coast early Thursday, Typhoon Ampil is expected to weaken and become a Category 3 hurricane by the time it reaches Tokyo on Friday evening. According to Japan's Joint Typhoon Warning Center, Ampil was registering winds of 140 kilometers per hour (85 miles per hour) as it was moving northeast, just north of Okinawa. 
Though the center of the typhoon is not expected to make landfall, Japan's public broadcaster NHK reports, two of the country's major airlines, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, have canceled about 500 flights to and from Tokyo's Haneda and Narita airports. 
The Category 3-equivalent storm is expected to weaken by the time it reaches cooler waters on Saturday.

title: Japan ends Nankai Trough mega quake alert
message:
Supermarkets put limits on purchases, including bottled water, after the government warned of a “mega quake” on Aug 8.
A Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) expert panel on Aug 8 released an advisory that there was a “relatively higher chance” of a Nankai Trough mega quake as powerful as 9 magnitude, after a 7.1-magnitude quake hit Japan’s south-west.
All segments of the Nankai Trough ruptured at once in 1707, unleashing an earthquake that remains the nation’s second-most powerful on record.
Japan has predicted a 70 to 80 per cent chance of a Nankai Trough mega quake occurring in the next 30 years.
The government’s worst-case scenario has estimated that a Nankai Trough mega quake and subsequent tsunami disaster could kill 323,000 people, destroy 2.38 million buildings and cause 220 trillion yen (S$2 trillion) of economic damage.

title: Japan set to lift  megaquake  warning
message:
TOKYO, Japan — Japan will lift its week-old "megaquake" warning later Thursday if there is no further major seismic activity, the disaster management minister said.
"The possibility of a major earthquake has not been eliminated," he said, urging citizens to regularly check their preparedness "for the major earthquake that is expected".
The advisory concerned the Nankai Trough "subduction zone" between two tectonic plates in the Pacific Ocean, where massive earthquakes have hit in the past.
Japan's government has previously said the next magnitude 8-9 megaquake along the Nankai Trough has a roughly 70 percent probability of striking within the next 30 years.
The Japan Meteorological Association (JMA) warning was the first under new rules drawn up after a 2011 quake, tsunami and nuclear disaster that left around 18,500 people dead or missing.
event_breakdown: Japan will lift a week-old megaquake warning later Thursday if there is no further significant seismic activity, Kazushi Gunji, Japan's disaster management minister, said Thursday.

title: Debby lifts area out of drought
message:
Most of South Carolina is now free from drought following the late-July rain and Tropical Storm Debby.
Orangeburg, Bamberg and Calhoun counties are no longer experiencing drought conditions.
In July, Orangeburg and Bamberg were in a moderate drought, while Calhoun was in a severe drought.
The drought status was downgraded only one level –from moderate to incipient – for Abbeville, McCormick, Edgefield, Greenwood and Laurens counties.
“As water levels return to a normal status, agricultural producers pray for somewhat normal growing conditions to finish out the 2024 growing season on a positive note.

event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Imelda

More than 1,000 residents had to evacuate their homes and 200 vehicles were stranded in floodwaters Thursday after Tropical Depression Imelda deluged southeast Texas with rain, officials said.

The flooding has closed major streets and highways around the city of Beaumont, leaving several neighborhoods inaccessible and prompting mandatory evacuations in some areas, the Beaumont Police Department said.

The National Weather Service said preliminary estimates showed that Jefferson County, which is home to Beaumont, received more than 35 inches of rain in less than three days.

"Jefferson County at this time is a disaster area," the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office said in a statement Thursday morning. "The sheriff's office primary focus is life safety and currently we are operating in rescue mode."

Port Arthur got an estimated 14 inches of rain overnight, mayor Thurman Bartie told ABC News.

"Most all of our streets are impassable," Barthie said. "We've got a lot of high water in places nobody's ever seen water in before."

He said the school district in Port Arthur was canceled for Thursday. The city asked residents to stay off the roads and move their vehicles to higher ground.

Houston officials said the historic flooding from Imelda wasn't near that of Hurricane Harvey, which dumped several feet of rain in the region in 2017.

Harris County Judge Ed Emmett said what's flooded this time is largely urban neighborhoods, which don't drain as well as rural land.

"Harvey was 1,000-year rain. This is more like a 100-year rain," he said

title: Forecast for Ernesto puts hurricane in Canadian waters by Monday , with track unclear – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
HALIFAX – Hurricane Ernesto is expected to track “well south” of Nova Scotia by the time the storm approaches the Atlantic region on Monday, the Canadian Hurricane Centre says.
Still, Nova Scotia and southeastern Newfoundland may receive some rain that day, the agency said in its Thursday afternoon forecast.
There is a low probability of winds in Nova Scotia and “a bit higher” chance of strong winds in Newfoundland, it added.
The long-term forecast for the track of hurricane Ernesto has it moving southeast of Nova Scotia, with the possibility of influencing weather in Newfoundland on Tuesday.
The Canadian Hurricane Centre said the warm ocean temperatures are playing a role in intensifying the storm near Bermuda.
location: HALIFAX - The Canadian Hurricane Centre said Ernesto is expected to track “well south”
event_breakdown: Halifax, Nova Scotia, August 3, 2022: Halifax is expected to see some rain from Hurricane Ernesto on Monday. "The hurricane center is projecting that Ernesto will strengthen over the weekend to a Category 2 or Category 3 hurricane," said meteorologist Bob Robichaud. "There's a lot of uncertainty in the forecast, but there's a possibility that the storm could track closer to Nova Scotia than it does at the moment." Nova Scotians can expect the rain to begin late Sunday and continue into early Monday. The province remains at "extremely high risk" of severe weather, according to the St. John's-based Canadian Hurricane Centre.

title: Japan lifts  megaquake  warning
message:
Japan lifted on Thursday a week-old warning that a "megaquake" potentially causing colossal damage and loss of life could strike, with the government telling people their lives could now "go back to normal".
The advisory concerned the Nankai Trough between two tectonic plates in the Pacific Ocean.
In 1707, all segments of the Nankai Trough ruptured at once, unleashing an earthquake that remains the nation's second-most powerful on record.
- Slower trains -Japan's government has previously said the next magnitude 8-9 megaquake along the Nankai Trough has a roughly 70 percent probability of striking within the next 30 years.
The megaquake warning even prompted Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to cancel a four-day trip to Central Asia due to take place last weekend.

message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto barreled toward Bermuda on Thursday after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water as sweltering heat enveloped the U.S. territory, raising concerns about people’s health.
La Plata river floods a road after Tropical Storm Ernesto passed through Toa Baja, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024.

At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

Tropical storm warnings were discontinued for Puerto Rico and its outlying islands of Vieques and Culebra and for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands.

title: Hurricane Ernesto churns toward Bermuda as Category 1 storm
message:
Hurricane Ernesto churns toward Bermuda as Category 1 stormHurricane Ernesto is expected to strengthen into a major hurricane over the coming days as it travels north toward Bermuda, having left half of Puerto Rico's residents without power.
Hurricane Ernesto has been fighting dry air on Thursday, limiting its ability to strengthen as it moves over open water north of Puerto Rico.
It is expected to gather strength through the coming weekend, possibly growing from a Category 1 to a Category 3 hurricane.
By Friday night, the storm is expected to approach Bermuda as a Category 2 hurricane with winds of up to 110 mph.
After churning past Bermuda, Ernesto is projected to continue north and brush the Canadian coast near Newfoundland.

title: Hurricane Ernesto To Create Dangerous Beach Conditions Along East Coast
message:
Hurricane Ernesto, the third hurricane of the season, is heading towards Bermuda, bringing with it the threat of life-threatening rip currents along the East Coast.
The hurricane, which has already caused damage in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, is currently moving north at 14 mph, just east of the Bahamas.
With maximum sustained winds of 85 mph, Ernesto is a Category 1 hurricane, just 9 mph away from a Category 2 designation, according to the National Hurricane Center.
While the storm is not projected to make direct landfall on the U.S., forecasters expect it to bring dangerous swells to the East Coast over the weekend.
The National Hurricane Center has warned people on the East Coast to prepare for a significant risk of life-threatening surf and rip currents.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto strengthens into hurricane after knocking out power in Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto strengthened into a hurricane on Wednesday, after bringing “significant flooding” to Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands and moved north.
More than 700,000 customers in Puerto Rico – half of all customers on the island – were without power Wednesday, according to LUMA Energy, the private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
President Biden approved an emergency declaration for Puerto Rico, with the White House saying they were authorizing FEMA to help with storm recovery.
The hurricane center said the storm is expected to produce between 4 and 6 inches of rain over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and up to 10 inches across southeastern Puerto Rico.
Flash flooding and mudslides could occur in the U.S. territories, the hurricane center said, as Ernesto continues bring “ongoing heavy rains.”Ernesto marks the fifth named storm so far of the Atlantic hurricane season.

title: Hurricane Ernesto tracking to hit Canada Atlantic
message:
Newfoundland and possibly Nova Scotia may be upcoming stops for Hurricane Ernesto after the category 3 hurricane barrels into the Caribbean.
Expected to hit Bermuda on Saturday, Ernesto looks ready to continue its path to Canada’s Atlantic coast as it tracks northeastward, the Canadian Hurricane Centre says.
“The hurricane is forecast to be rather large, intensify to category-3 level, and generate large ocean swell that will begin arriving along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia on Saturday,” says the Canadian Hurricane Centre.
Beachgoers and sightseers are encouraged to exercise caution,” says the Canadian Hurricane Centre.

title: Japan lifts  megaquake  warning
message:
The advisory concerned the Nankai Trough between two tectonic plates in the Pacific Ocean.
In 1707, all segments of the Nankai Trough ruptured at once, unleashing an earthquake that remains the nation's second-most powerful on record.
Japan's government has previously said the next magnitude 8-9 megaquake along the Nankai Trough has a roughly 70 percent probability of striking within the next 30 years.
The megaquake warning even prompted Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to cancel a four-day trip to Central Asia due to take place last weekend.
The Japan Meteorological Association (JMA) warning was the first under new rules drawn up after a 2011 quake, tsunami and nuclear disaster that left around 18,500 people dead or missing.
event_breakdown: Japan's government said Friday that a magnitude 8-9 earthquake that experts warn could devastate Tokyo and nearby regions will not occur over the coming month but added the timeframe is not long enough to completely rule out a massive jolt.

message:

title: Japan Earthquake Advisory : Japan first - ever megaquake advisory brings worry and confusion . What does it mean ?
message:
Q: What prompted Japan to issue its first-ever "megaquake advisory"?
Q: What is the Nankai Trough, and why is it significant?
Q: How severe could a megaquake in the Nankai Trough be?
Japan has taken an unprecedented step in earthquake preparedness by issuing its first-ever " megaquake advisory" following a significant magnitude 7.1 earthquake off the southeastern coast of Kyushu on August 8.
Despite the advisory, JMA experts reassured the public on Monday that no abnormal seismic activity indicating an imminent megaquake had been detected.The advisory has caused widespread confusion and concern.
location:
)
The Nankai Trough off the southeastern coast of Kyushu, Japan
event_breakdown:
Nankai Trough
Japan issues unprecedented "megaquake advisory"
The Nankai Trough is a significant submarine trough located just off the coast of the southwest coast of Japan. It stretches from central Japan to the Nansei Shoto region of the southwest. The trough is a significant seismic hazard, as it runs along the boundary between the subducting Philippine Sea Plate and the overriding Eurasian Plate.
The trough is home to large amounts of seismic activity, including earthquakes and tsunamis. The 2011 Tohoku earthquake, which caused widespread destruction in Japan, was triggered by the Nankai Trough's activity. The earthquake was a powerful magnitude 9.0 earthquake, and it triggered a massive tsunami that caused widespread damage across Japan's coast.
The Nankai Trough is also home to other active and dormant volcanoes, including the Mt. Fuji Volcano. The trough is the most significant seismic and volcanic hazard in Japan, and it is also one of the most significant in Japan's history.

title: Japan cancels flights and suspends bullet trains ahead of Typhoon Ampil
message:
As of early Thursday local time, Typhoon Ampil was recording sustained winds of 140 kph (85 mph), according to the latest advisory from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC).
By Friday evening, as it nears Japan southeast of Tokyo, it could become the equivalent of a Category 3 hurricane, according to a JTWC forecast.
Two major airlines, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, canceled about 500 flights in total serving the capital’s Haneda and Narita airports, according to public broadcaster NHK.
The storm’s center is expected to remain slightly offshore as it turns toward the northeast and moves away from Japan, according to JTWC and Japan’s Meteorological Agency.
The storm is expected to weaken by Saturday morning local time and die down as it moves into cooler waters over the weekend.

“It’s just frustrating that this many years later, we continue to see something like a storm cause such widespread outages in Puerto Rico, particularly given the risk that these outages can cause for vulnerable households in Puerto Rico,” said Charlotte Gossett Navarro, the Hispanic Federation’s chief director for Puerto Rico.

title: Moderate earthquake : M5 . 4 quake has struck near Yilan in Taiwan
message:
A moderate earthquake magnitude 5.4 (ml/mb) strikes 44 kilometers (27 miles) from Yilan in Taiwan on Thursday.
Exact time and date of earthquake 15/08/24 / 2024-08-15 09:06:45 / August 15, 2024 @ 9:06 am UTC/GMT.
The epicenter was at a depth of 11.345 km (7 miles).
Nearby country/countries that might be effected, Taiwan (c. 22 894 000 pop).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, that has occurred near: 44 km SSE of Yilan, Taiwan.
event_breakdown:
Event: A moderate earthquake magnitude 5.4 (ml/mb) strikes 44 kilometers (27 miles) from Yilan in Taiwan on Thursday.
An earthquake of magnitude 5.4 occurred 44 kilometers (27 miles) southeast of Yilan, Taiwan on Thursday. The epicenter was at a depth of 11.345 kilometers (7 miles). The event has been categorized as a moderate earthquake. There were no reports of injuries or damage.
